DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US announced to delay tariffs on some items from China until December 15th including mobile phones, laptops, computers, video games, certain toys, computer monitors, some footwear and clothing items, while USTR also noted that some products are being removed from the China tariff list and that the products will not be subject to the additional 10% tariff based on health, safety, national security and other factors.

US President Trump confirmed that tariffs were delayed for the Christmas season in case it had an impact on shopping and that he has always been optimistic about a China trade deal. Trump also commented that stock markets are up for a few reasons including tariffs and that his call with China was very productive, while he suggested that so far China has not bought "big" from US farmers and that "maybe this will be different". (Twitter)

China Global Times cited experts in which it noted that delaying 10% tariff on China's electronic products shows Beijing’s retaliation measures, with yuan’s depreciation, have been taking a bigger-than-expected toll on US economy amid the trade war and that it is pushing the US to show a goodwill gesture to create environment for trade talks. (Twitter)

China's Vice Premier Liu reportedly spoke with USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin. There were also reports that China’s MOFCOM reportedly did not agree to anything in return to US President Trump's December 15th Tariff delay on certain goods and stated that further US-China talks are planned in the next 2 weeks. (Xinhua/Twitter/Fox)

A court issued an injunction to remove Hong Kong protesters, while there were also reports of severe disruptions at Hong Kong’s airport due to a public assembly and that Hong Kong police was said to have entered the airport terminal with riot gear in which they used pepper spray against protestors. (Newswires)

China's Mission to the UN rejected the UN's statement on Hong Kong and criticized it as interfering in China's domestic affairs which sends the wrong signal to violent criminal offenders. Furthermore, China alleged that Hong Kong protesters are "showing a tendency of resorting to terrorism", while there were separate comments from the Global Times Editor that Beijing intervention in Hong Kong could be inevitable. (Newswires/Twitter) 

 

UK/EU

The legal bid to stop UK PM Johnson from forcing a no-deal Brexit by suspending parliament will have a full hearing on September 6th. (Politico)

US & Britain are discussing a partial trade agreement which could take effect on November 1st which is 1 day after the Brexit according to a senior Trump Official, while an official also stated that US National Security Advisor Bolton and UK Trade Secretary Truss talked about the potential for signing a road map declaration towards a trade deal at the G7. (Newswires)

Italian Senate rejected League's call for a no confidence vote in parliament on Wednesday and are to debate the no confidence motion in parliament on August 20th, while it was also reported that Deputy PM Salvini proposed accepting 5SM's demand to reduce the number of politicians quickly but added that Italy must then hold elections. (Newswires)

German Parliament 2020 draft budget foresees no net debt increase and Germany to issue EUR 234bln in gross debt in 2020 (from EUR 185bln Y/Y), while reports noted that Chancellor Merkel does not see any need for fiscal stimulus at the moment and will act according to the situation. (Newswires)

  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Jun) 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%) 
  • UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jun) 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.6%) 
  • UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M (Jun) Y/Y 3.7% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.4%, Rev. 3.5%) 
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Aug) -44.1 vs. Exp. -28.5 (Prev. -24.5) 
  • German ZEW Current Conditions (Aug) -13.5 vs. Exp. -7.0 (Prev. -1.1) 

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories +3.7mln vs. Exp. -2.8mln (Prev. -3.4mln). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif says insecurity in Persian Gulf is caused by US intervention and that foreign fleets in this region "increases risks of combustion", while he also stated that the US' proliferation of arms in our region is a menace to regional security. (Newswires)

 

US

  • US CPI (Jul) M/M 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) 
  • US CPI (Jul) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.6%) 
  • US Core CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Sour risk sentiment reversed after the US open on news that the US would be delaying some tariffs on Chinese imports that were due to become effective on 1st September. There are some questions about the motivations of the move; while it can be spun as a de-escalation of trade wars, Trump justified the move in case it had an impact on shopping during the Christmas season, suggesting it was more about domestic politics rather than a move to appease China. Nonetheless, the announcement saw risk assets bounce (stocks moved into positive territory, Treasuries went negative), while EMFX gained against the USD, and the bid in havens deflated. All sectors closed green, with defensive utilities underperforming. Tech shares outperformed after the delayed tariffs were announced for many tech items, and as it is a key sector which holds exposure to China given the semiconductor presence. The Computer and Electronics Retail sub index outperformed. As the haven bid deflated, gold gave back some gains, which weighed on the Gold sub index. Homebuilders were higher following initiations from SunTrust, with new buys for DR Horton (DHI) & Pulte (PHM), and new holds for Lennar (LEN) & Toll Brothers (TOL). Elsewhere, General Electric (GE) firmed after its CEO purchased USD 3mln of shares. Micron Technologies (MU) and other semiconductor names benefited as US President Trump delayed some tariffs on items, such as mobile phones, laptops & computers -- products which use chips. Apple (AAPL) traded higher on positive trade developments too, however, it’s Airpods, Homepod and Apple Watch do remain on the list of September 1st tariffs. S&P 500 +1.5%, NASDAQ 100 +2.2%, DJIA +1.4%.

The Treasury curve bear-flattened in Tuesday trade. There was much attention on the 2s10s part of the Treasury curve, which came to within 1 bps of inversion, before US/China news allowed a bounce. However, at settlement, the gap is around 2bps, keeping the threat of inversion alive. The 3m/10-year part of the curve was also in focus, but is already inverted, of course; the gap here went as deep as -40bps in overnight trade, but has pared back to around -33bps amid more constructive risk sentiment. The long-end of the curve continues to gain attention, with yields down to fresh 37-month lows. This has also been a focus of equity traders; with regards to the 10s sector, Goldman Sachs noted that the S&P 500 currently offers a trailing 12-month dividend yield of 2.0% – higher than the 10-year US Treasury yield for the first time since October 2016. At settlement, major US curve spreads had tightened, with 2s30 narrowing by around 6bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 17+ lower at 129-26+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap -  13th August 2019: Risk assets bounce after US delays some tariffs on China
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: US to delay some China tariffs; US CPI firms in July; Grim German ZEW; US 2s10s almost inverts; violent clashes reported in HK; Italy lawmakers fail to set confidence vote date.
  • COMING UP: Chinese Industrial Production, Retail Sales; German GDP; EZ GDP; Australian Wage Price Index, RBA Debelle; UK CPI, PPI and RPI; Swedish CPI.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Sour risk sentiment reversed after the US open on news that the US would be delaying some tariffs on Chinese imports that were due to become effective on 1st September. There are some questions about the motivations of the move; while it can be spun as a de-escalation of trade wars, Trump justified the move in case it had an impact on shopping during the Christmas season, suggesting it was more about domestic politics rather than a move to appease China. Nonetheless, the announcement saw risk assets bounce (stocks moved into positive territory, Treasuries went negative), while EMFX gained against the USD, and the bid in havens deflated. The moves were challenged after tensions in Hong Kong heated up, and riot police removed protestors

* CHINA TARIFFS: The US will delay until 15th December the 10% tariff on USD 300bln of Chinese imports (the fourth tranche of tariffs) on some items (cell phones, laptop computers, video game consoles, certain toys, computer monitors, and certain items of footwear and clothing; some tariffs will take effect on 1st September, as planned), Bloomberg reported. The implication is that the monetary size of the tariff list has been significantly cut - the cellphones component alone accounted for USD 45bln of the tariffs (using 2017 data as a proxy). On the face of it, the news could also be seen as a de-escalation of trade wars that helps engineer positive talks between the US and China; however, Bloomberg's reported noted that the US concession appears designed to avoid any disruption or price increases for US consumers heading into the holiday season, according to the report. The announcement also came as the two sides spoke for the first time since the recent escalation in tensions, and another conference call is planned again in two weeks. China's Global Times, a state mouth piece, responded that the delay to the tariffs shows "Beijing’s retaliation measures, with yuan’s depreciation, have been taking a bigger-than-expected toll on US economy amid trade war, pushing US to show goodwill gesture to create environment for trade talks."

* HONG KONG: Protestors returned to Hong Kong International Airport, which resulted in further flight cancellations; riot police responded to the situation, and clashed with protestors. China authorities once again suggested that protestors were "showing tendencies of resorting to terrorism" which some analysts take as a pre-justification to use a heavier hand with protestors (it was reported on Monday that armed police were assembling in Shenzen, which borders Hong Kong, which is seen as a threat of possible action if the situation deteriorates). Analysts are now keeping an eye out for signs that authorities will take a firmer hand (see our analysis here).

* US CPI: Headline CPI rose +0.3% M/M, in line with expectations, though the Y/Y rate firmed by more than expected, to 1.8% from 1.6% (consensus 1.7%). The core metrics rose by 0.3% M/M, a quicker pace than the 0.2% expected, but matching the prior; the Y/Y rate also rose by more than expected, to 2.2% against an expected unchanged 2.1%). Real weekly earnings fell by 0.3% M/M in July, against the previous +0.2%. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that the overshoot was due to gains in used car prices, medical services and airline fares, as well as tobacco and apparel. Rents were subdued, but Pantheon sees no reason to expect a fundamental slowing, given the very low vacancy rate and rising wages. "After four straight core CPI increases of less than 0.15% per month, two straight 0.29% gains are more likely to be just a rebound rather than the start of a sustained trend, the consultancy says, "that's almost certainly the case with used auto prices, which plunged in the first few months of the year but are now rebounding." However, the increases in other components may persist, due to rising labour costs and tariffs: "The upturn in medical services inflation, where the Y/Y rate has risen to 3.3% in July from just 1.9% last October, looks like a response to the tight labour market," and "the 3-month annualized rate is a startling 5.7%, so the Y/Y rate likely has further to climb," Pantheon writes. "But the surge in furniture and bedding inflation, to 3.9% in July, and the 6.0% Y/Y rise in prices for floor coverings, are tariff effects, and offer a taste of what would happen if the administration imposes tariffs on a wide range of imported Chinese consumer goods next month." Pantheon argues that, even without further tariffs, core CPI inflation may rise to 2.5% Y/Y by the end of 2019, with unfavourable base effects then likely to push it close to 3% by next spring. "The three-month annualized rate now is at 2.8%, and is likely to breach 3% in August, for the first time in eight years," Pantheon says, "under normal circumstances, this would have the Fed tightening, but the trade war has changed everything, and another easing in September -- 25bp rather than 50bp -- remains our base case. The endless easing expected by markets, however, will come only if the economy rolls over, if inflation rises as we expect."

* GERMANY ZEW: The ZEW expectations index dropped to -44.0, down sharply from the prior -24.5 in July, and much weaker than the consensus -28.0. Pantheon Macroeconomics said that this was a dreadful headline, similar to the depths reached during the financial crisis in 2008 and in late 2011, when the US debt ceiling crisis roiled markets: "On this occasion, however, it seems as if investors are anticipating chaos — a US-Sino currency war, Brexit etc—or at least ascribing a very high probability to an accident," Pantheon says, "in other words, there is little current justification in the equity market, which is usually the best short-term gauge for the ZEW, for this crash." Pantheon says that the details show that investors’ interest rate expectations slid further in Q3, consistent with market-based gauges pointing to further rate cuts by the Fed, and a reduction in the deposit rate in the Eurozone too. "Expectations also dipped for equities, though they remain broadly balanced, expect for markets in the UK and Italy where investors are clearly factoring-in political risks."

* ITALY: PM Conte will appear before lawmakers on 20th August, as they debate the confidence motion against the government. Lawmakers were expected to today set a date; a motion to vote on Wednesday by League Leader Salvini was voted down – Salvini has been seeking a quick confidence vote that would lead to quick elections and allow his League Party to make gains at the polls and influence the 2020 Budget. That decision is to be left to the Italian President Mattarella, who has been angling for the Budget to be passed before an election. Salvini today proposed accepting 5SM's demand to reduce the number of politicians quickly in return for quick elections, a measure seen as an olive branch to progress proceedings; analysts had noted that the proposal to cut MPs from 945 to 600 has been approved by parliament on three occasions, with the fourth vote due in September. HSBC says that completing this reform would mean elections could not take place for another 5-6 months at least, due to the need to allow a possible referendum to be called, and to re-draw the electoral council boundaries. The key implication of today’s events is that there is still no clarity on when a confidence measure will take place, when elections will take place; there is also no clarity on the sequencing of events.

* BREXIT: A ComRes poll shows that 54% of those polled back the statement that "Boris Johnson needs to deliver Brexit by any means, including suspending parliament if necessary, in order to prevent MPs (Members of Parliament) from stopping it." Newspapers are also heavily carrying news from Monday, where US National Security Advisor Bolton said the US would 'enthusiastically' support the UK in the event of a no deal Brexit, and that the US could be willing to make sector-by-sector deals following Brexit.

* UK JOBS REPORT: While the jobless rate moved 0.1ppts higher to 3.9% in the three-months to June, against a consensus view for unchanged. However, the wages data was more encouraging, coming in line with expectations at 3.7% for the rise in weekly wages, and 3.4% for the measure that includes bonuses. The data is good enough to undermine the case for BOE rate cuts, Pantheon Macroeconomics argues: employment was 115K (+0.4%) higher in the three months to June than in the previous three months, above the 89K average increase seen since the Brexit vote in 2016, and the proportion of employees in temporary roles remains at the lowest since records began in 1992, while slack is not increasing meaningfully. Pantheon concedes that the labour market tends to lag developments in the wider economy, but notes that firms have lived with high levels of economic uncertainty for the best part of a year, and still want to fill new positions; vacancies were 20K, or 2.3%, lower in the three months to July than in the three months to April, Pantheon says, but remained high both by historical standards and in relation to unemployment. Meanwhile, the employment components of business surveys generally have recovered since Q1 and are consistent with solid year-over-year growth in employee numbers of about 1% in the second half of this year. "As a result, wage growth should continue to exceed productivity gains by a large margin," Pantheon writes, "the pick-up in the headline rate of wage growth excluding bonuses to an 11-year high of 3.9% in June, from 3.6% in May, entirely reflects near-term momentum"; the analysts also note that the annualised rate of three-month-on-three-month growth in wages -- cited by the MPC to support past increases in Bank Rate -- leapt to 4.8% in June, from 3.9% in May. "So in the event that Brexit is delayed further—still our base case—or an agreement is reached in October and the economy starts to rebuild a little momentum, the MPC will need to move in short order to raise Bank Rate again."

* WTI (U9) SETTLES USD 2.17 HIGHER AT USD 57.10/BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 2.73 HIGHER AT USD 61.30/BBL: The crude complex has rallied on Tuesday on positive US-China trade developments, which are seen as supportive for the demand-side of the oil equation, where much focus has been placed of late. “Demand fears that were a big factor in recent price weakness have eased,” Citi said, and the bank also notes that “the Brent market has joined the party, now catching up with some of the recent stronger gains in WTI. After market, participants will be looking ahead to the US energy inventories, with the API reporting after the bell on Tuesday. The latest week’s inventory expectations see crude stocks -2.8mln bbls, gasoline unchanged, and distillates +1mln bbls; Genscape forecasts Cushing at -2.5mln bbls.

* IRAN: Gibraltar denied earlier reports that the oil tanker Grace 1 will be leaving British Overseas Territory on Tuesday. It was previously reported that the Iranian tanker seized by the UK, Grace 1, will be freed by Tuesday Evening, FARS reported, citing Gibraltarian authorities; the detainment extension is set to expire on August 15th. The Grace 1 was seized on July 4th on allegations that the Iranian tanker was shipping oil to Syria, which would be a violation of existing EU sanctions, although Iran has denied the claims and has since seized a British tanker (Stena Impero) in the Strait of Hormuz, accusing it of marine violations.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 17+ LOWER AT 129-26+. The Treasury curve bear-flattened in Tuesday trade. There was much attention on the 2s10s part of the Treasury curve, which came to within 1 bps of inversion, before US/China news allowed a bounce. However, at settlement, the gap is around 2bps, keeping the threat of inversion alive. The 3m/10-year part of the curve was also in focus, but is already inverted, of course; the gap here went as deep as -40bps in overnight trade, but has pared back to around -33bps amid more constructive risk sentiment. The long-end of the curve continues to gain attention, with yields down to fresh 37-month lows. This has also been a focus of equity traders; with regards to the 10s sector, Goldman Sachs noted that the S&P 500 currently offers a trailing 12-month dividend yield of 2.0% – higher than the 10-year US Treasury yield for the first time since October 2016. At settlement, major US curve spreads had tightened, with 2s30 narrowing by around 6bps.

* FX WRAP: The USD strengthened in wake of firm CPI data, and combined with positive developments on the US/China trade front, yields rose across the curve, helping USDJPY pare back earlier, haven flow-induced losses. Gold is negative, though is holding above the USD 1500 mark, while the Swissy is negative. The positive trade news gave risk assets a bounce, and USDCNH managed to print a low sub-7.00, helping USD/EM to fall. The EUR was still in positive territory after a grim ZEW report, but went negative amid USD strength post CPI. GBP trades slightly negative, despite a wave of headlines suggesting the US and UK could strike a trade deal as soon as the UK exits Europe; that said, the 1.2015 low from Monday was untested. AUD has been well supported at 0.6750, but moved closer to 0.68 in wake of the trade news; the currency largely ignore NAB survey and RBA Kent comments overnight. USDCAD breached 1.32 to the downside; analysts note that the currency is a good proxy for risk sentiment, however, it could not hold sub 1.32.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: General Electric (GE) firmed after its CEO purchased USD 3mln of shares. Micron Technologies (MU) and other semiconductor names benefited as US President Trump delayed some tariffs on items, such as mobile phones, laptops & computers -- products which use chips. Apple (AAPL) traded higher on positive trade developments too, however, it’s Airpods, Homepod and Apple Watch do remain on the list of September 1st tariffs.

* STOCK SECTORS: All sectors closed green, with defensive utilities underperforming. Tech shares outperformed after the delayed tariffs were announced for many tech items, and as it is a key sector which holds exposure to China given the semiconductor presence. The Computer and Electronics Retail sub index outperformed. As the haven bid deflated, gold gave back some gains, which weighed on the Gold sub index. Homebuilders were higher following initiations from SunTrust, with new buys for DR Horton (DHI) & Pulte (PHM), and new holds for Lennar (LEN) & Toll Brothers (TOL).

* M&A: CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) finally reached an agreement to merge where the new company will be called ViacomCBS, with Bob Bakish (Viacom’s CEO) to lead the company. Joe laniello, who was CEO last year, will be the chairman of CBS and in charge of CBS assets following the merger. Shari Redstone, who controls CBS and Viacom with her father through their family holding company, National Amusements, has advocated for the deal to gather larger financial holdings to help compete against media and tech heavyweights Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL) for entertainment and sports rights, most notably, the NFL. CBS owns rights to the NFL until 2022 and “will do what is necessary” to renew them. Shari Redstone is to lead the board of directors.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: risk revival as US-China talk trade and tariff concessions made
content:
DXY

The index and Greenback in general gleaned some traction from firmer than forecast US inflation data, but the rebound gathered pace and was exacerbated by latest developments on the US-China trade front. In short, Chinese President VP Liu is said to have spoken to USTR Lighthizer and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and the top officials will hold follow-up talks in a fortnight (presumably to see if face-to-face meetings will take place in September), while in the interim Washington has decided to waiver some additional 10% tariffs and defer others until mid-December. The upshot, a broad upturn in flagging sentiment to the detriment of safe-havens, with the DXYup to 97.788 vs 97.315 in the run up to the CPI release.

AUD/JPY 

The meltdown in Gold (back below Usd1500/oz) and reversal in Usd/Cnh (from 7.1060+ to sub-7.0000) highlight the extent of the turnaround in risk appetite from earlier (selective) aversion, but in major markets the marked change in mood is clear in Aud/Usd’s extended rebound through 0.6800 and Usd/Jpy’s even bigger resurgence from near 105.00 lows to almost 107.00.

NOK/SEK

Also beneficiaries of the vastly improved tone (or sheer relief), as Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek recoiled from 10.0160+ and 10.7300+ to circa 9.9245 and 10.6575 respectively, and the Norwegian Krona derived added impetus from a decent pre-API recovery in oil prices, like the Loonie (Usd/CAD back under 1.3200 vs just shy of 1.3300 at one stage). Note, if relations between Washington and Beijing continue to thaw this may underpin Norges Bank and Riksbank intentions to press ahead with further policy normalisation as well.

EUR/CHF/GBP

The single currency got caught up in the unwind of safe-haven positioning having shown resilience in the face of a downbeat ZEW survey, and Eur/Usd topped out just above recent peaks to trade back below 1.1200 and close to August lows. Similarly, less demand for the Franc saw Usd/Chf rebound from around 0.9660 to 0.9765 or so and even Eur/Chf reclaim the 1.0900 handle from sub-1.0850, which should appease the SNB to a degree. Meanwhile, Sterling remained relatively sluggish on no deal Brexit risk and UK political jitters with Cable hardly building on mild post-UK pay inspired gains and fading into 1.2100.

EM

Yuan aside, the breaking US-China headlines helped the likes of the Rand, Rouble, Real and both Pesos (Mexican and Argentine) regain some composure against the Buck, but the Lira continued to lag/underperform on technical factors as Usd/Try breached or probed through 200 and 21 DMAs. However, the proof of the pudding in terms of overall risk morale may well lie with the next PBoC 

USD/CNY

 mid-point fix after a gradual incline in official settings to 7.0421 overnight.

subject: ANALYSIS: US CPI firms in July, gives clues about what may happen if US raises tariffs on China in September
content:
• Headline CPI rose +0.3% M/M, in line with expectations, though the Y/Y rate firmed by more than expected, to 1.8% from 1.6% (consensus 1.7%). The core metrics rose by 0.3% M/M, a quicker pace than the 0.2% expected, but matching the prior; the Y/Y rate also rose by more than expected, to 2.2% against an expected unchanged 2.1%). Real weekly earnings fell by 0.3% M/M in July, against the previous +0.2%.
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that the overshoot was due to gains in used car prices, medical services and airline fares, as well as tobacco and apparel. Rents were subdued, but Pantheon sees no reason to expect a fundamental slowing, given the very low vacancy rate and rising wages.
  • "After four straight core CPI increases of less than 0.15% per month, two straight 0.29% gains are more likely to be just a rebound rather than the start of a sustained trend, the consultancy says, "that's almost certainly the case with used auto prices, which plunged in the first few months of the year but are now rebounding."
  • However, the increases in other components may persist, due to rising labour costs and tariffs: "The upturn in medical services inflation, where the Y/Y rate has risen to 3.3% in July from just 1.9% last October, looks like a response to the tight labor market," and "the 3-month annualized rate is a startling 5.7%, so the Y/Y rate likely has further to climb," Pantheon writes. "But the surge in furniture and bedding inflation, to 3.9% in July, and the 6.0% Y/Y rise in prices for floor coverings, are tariff effects, and offer a taste of what would happen if the administration imposes tariffs on a wide range of imported Chinese consumer goods next month."
  • Pantheon argues that, even without further tariffs, core CPI inflation may rise to 2.5% Y/Y by the end of 2019, with unfavorable base effects then likely to push it close to 3% by next spring. "The three-month annualized rate now is at 2.8%, and is likely to breach 3% in August, for the first time in eight years," Pantheon says, "under normal circumstances, this would have the Fed tightening, but the trade war has changed everything, and another easing in September -- 25bp rather than 50bp -- remains our base case. The endless easing expected by markets, however, will come only if the economy rolls over, if inflation rises as we expect."

ANALYSIS: How might Beijing intervene to stabilise Hong Kong? Factors to watch
content:
Geopolitical analysts at Stratfor says we should watch the following:

  • Watch the actions by mainland officials: "When top Chinese leaders emerge at some point in the next two weeks from their summer retreat in Beidaihe, their statements will indicate how they intend to approach Hong Kong," Stratfor writes, "Any move to convene a National People's Congress standing committee, which would be the body that would debate imposing a curfew in Hong Kong, would be a strong indicator that an intervention is imminent."
  • Watch the movement of mainland forces: "Any movements of the large forces purportedly gathered in Guangdong province to mark the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China or of the armed police stationed in Shenzhen should be monitored."
  • Watch the protesters' responses: Stratfor notes that, though Beijing's ongoing warnings that it might intervene could persuade protesters to act with more restraint, it is more likely to provoke them to stay the course. "Any intensification of unrest would make an intervention more likely."
  • Watch the responses from abroad: "Some in the United States, such as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have suggested sanctioning Beijing in the event of a violent crackdown on protesters in Hong Kong, though US President Trump has said Hong Kong is an internal matter for Beijing. "Officials have also suggested that Hong Kong could lose its special trade and customs regime in the event of a crackdown, though opinions on this are divided because doing so would also cost the United States," Stratfor says, "if the United States did proceed, Hong Kong would stand to lose a great deal from US tariff measures, which would harm its currency and financial markets, and in the long term, its status as a financial hub."
  • Watch the market reaction: "Even though Beijing's intervention might end the protests in the short term, the prospect of direct intervention by Beijing will further rattle the territory's economy, which has already been rocked by the weeks of violence," and "given Hong Kong's position as a world financial center and a critical financial link to the outside world for Beijing, any serious financial disruptions would harm mainland and territory alike."

subject: US is reportedly probing imports of devices with multi-function emulators
US July CPI Preview (1330 BST/0830 EDT): headline seen at 0.3% M/M (prev. 0.1%), and +1.7% Y/Y (prev. 1.6%); the core is seen at +0.2% (prev. +0.3%), and 2.1% Y/Y (prev. 2.1%)
content:
• UBS is optimistic about the data, noting that after small rises in the last two months, we could see a “solid” print (it sees +0.3% M/M).
  • The headline is likely to be driven higher by gasoline prices.
  • The core measure may be more subdued; it rose strongly in June, after four months of weak readings, and as such, there could even be some slowing
  • There will be an eye on the impact of tariffs; UBS says the pass-through could be supportive of consumer price inflation, particularly the household furnishings, which contains many goods that were subject to higher tariffs in May, which also saw rises in June.
  • The bank expects further pass-through in the months’ ahead, but notes the fourth tranche of tariffs, which will kick in in September, will be focussed on clothes, cell phones, and computing items. Looking ahead, the bank sees Y/Y remaining steady, but does see some declines later in the year.

subject: BAML August Fund Manager Survey (FMS): Investors most bullish on rates since 2008 as trade war concerns send recession risk to 8-year high
content:
• The nut: August Fund Manager Survey (FMS) is the most bullish on rates since 2008, BofAML says, as trade war concerns send recession risk to 8-year high; investors slash exposure to cyclicals to buy US Treasuries and US growth stocks; with global policy stimuli at a 2.5-year low, onus is on Fed/ECB/PBoC to restore animal spirits.
  • On growth: One-third of FMS investors expect a global recession in the next 12 months, the highest since 2011.
  • On policy: FMS investors say global fiscal and monetary policy mix is the most hawkish since November 2016; only 9% see higher bond yields in the next 12 months, the most bullish stance on rates since 2008.
  • On leverage: Half of FMS investors say corporates are excessively leveraged, a new record; investors want corporates to use cash to improve balance sheets > capex or buybacks.
  • On risk appetite: in contrast to June, the FMS cash level did not surge as growth expectations plunged. August cash levels fell from 5.2% to 5.1%; BofAML Bull & Bear Indicator holds at 3.7 (not extreme bearish though record net % say they have taken out protection).
  • On rotation: FMS investors sold cyclical value (Japan at 7-year low, industrials 2nd biggest MoM drop ever), bought defensives/growth (staples, tech) & bonds (#1 most crowded FMS trade is long US Treasuries); “growth over value” highest since GFC, the bank says.
  • On US: FMS investors say US equities are the most preferred region over the next 12 months despite 78% saying the region is overvalued; note combination of two 2nd most extreme on record (#1 Aug’18).
  • On bubbles: FMS investors say biggest central bank-induced bubble risk in: #1 corporate bonds (33%), #2 Govt bonds (30%), #3 US equities (26%), #4 gold (8%). FMS contrarian trades: contrarians should be long inflation vs. deflation assets (equities>bonds, Japan>US, industrials>pharma).

ANALYSIS: Italy government confidence vote
content:
*FALLOUT – Italian Senate leaders yesterday failed to reach a consensus on the timing of a no-confidence vote against the Conte-led government, and thus will reconvene today at 1700 BST to continue its debate. ANSA reported that the PM will likely be invited to address senate on August 20th, with desks speculating that this will be when his fate will be decided.

*PM SALVINI? – Once debated, the no-confidence vote is expected to pass. Forza Italia and Brothers of Italy leaders have both previously pledged support to Salvini. PD (centre-left) are also likely to back the no-confidence vote, as polling suggests it could leave them as primary opposition rather than Di-Maio’s 5SM. Latest polls register Salvini’s League between 36-38%, with a snap election upping the prospect of an outright majority in both branches of parliament. However, analysts note that an alliance with the Brothers of Italy (far-right) might provide some comfort, add to that the Forza Italia (centre-right), Salvini may reach the 2/3 majority required to amend Italy’s constitution.

*TECHNOCRATIC GOVERNMENT? - Mattarella has previously spoken about the importance of pushing through the 2020 Budget (due Oct 20th) , and as such, Goldman believes risks are tilted in this direction, “however, it is not clear at this stage whether there will be a majority in Parliament to support a caretaker/institutional government." Goldman says that a caretaker government would be near-term bullish news for financial markets, while a general election in Q4 (given Lega's strength in recent opinion polls) would be near-term bearish, as investors would be likely to price-in a higher risk of a further weakening of the public finance outlook, of rating agency downgrades and of a more confrontational dialogue with European partners regarding both fiscal rules and immigration. Reports also speculated that the President could seek a “guarantee government”, i.e. a coalition that can ensure the functioning of government. Salvini has dismissed this notion as undemocratic, and favours elections

*WHAT TO EXPECT - It is likely that Conte’s government no longer has majority. The real question, Goldman Sachs says, is whether President Mattarella will opt for a caretaker government (to vote through the 2020 Budget in Q4), or whether Italians will go to the polls at the back-end October or November (which would leave the current government in power to manage affairs until the election). Deputy PM Salvini reportedly favours 13th October as a date for an election, although others noted that President Mattarella is mulling 23rd October, subject to the timing of the confidence vote. It’s also worth keeping in mind that late October will be risk-packed, with Italy’s 2020 budget (Oct 20th), Brexit day (Oct 31st), the appointment of newly elected EU leaders/ECB President (Nov 1st) all on the docket alongside potential Italian elections.

subject: Gibralter Government source has denied earlier reports that oil tanker Grace 1 will be leaving British Overseas Territory on Tuesday
analysis_details: NOTE: It was earlier reported that the Iranian tanker Grace 1 tanker, seized by the UK, will be freed by Tuesday Evening, FARS reported, citing Gibraltarian authorities. The detainment extension was set to expire on August 15th. The Grace 1 was seized on July 4th on allegations that the Iranian tanker was shipping oil to Syria, which would be a violation of existing EU sanctions, although Iran has denied the claims and has since seized a British tanker (Stena Impero) in the Strait of Hormuz, accusing it of marine violations.

subject: Metro (B4B GY) has extended China unit sale deadline until next week, according to sources
Fund managers says early indications show Argentine bond prices up around 0.5 cents, following the heavy sell-off on Monday
analysis_details: After the weekend's primaries, fears of a full-blown financial crisis have returned as the market-friendly incumbent President Macri's chances of winning look diminished. UBS thinks that his priority now is delivering macroeconomic stability ahead of elections. But the main question, UBS says, is whether authorities have enough fire power to defend the peso, especially if there is a run on deposits. The bank notes that Argentines have increased dollarisation in recent months, so much of the exodus out of the peso is already likely to have been seen. UBS notes that authorities can intervene intra FX band up to unspecified amounts (over and above the USD 60mln being sold daily by the central bank on behalf of the Treasury) and they can sell up to USD 250mln daily in the event that the peso breaches the top of the band (51.50 to the dollar). The bank also notes that in addition to spot sales, the IMF recently allowed Argentina to increase its sale of non-deliverable forwards to USD 3.6bln through the end of September. "FX intervention would be non-sterilized, tightening the monetary supply and raising interest rates in the process," UBS writes, "the Central Bank is currently sitting on USD 29bln in net reserves (equivalent to 205% of sight deposits and 60% of M2), but it is unclear how much the IMF and the authorities would be prepared to burn to stabilize the currency and validate the capital flight." Argentine authorities will also have to contend with high rollover risk of short-term Treasury debt. "By the IMF's estimates, for the 2019 financing program to balance, the rollover rate had be a high 80% in the remainder of the year. This threshold now looks extremely challenging."

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are lower [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.5%] as sentiment remains risk off as the geopolitical situation remains tense with dismal German data not helping
  • Hong Kong's airport has reportedly suspended all check-ins, following online calls for another day of public assembly
  • USD is mixed between G10 counterparts with antipodeans and safe-havens outperforming and EM’s lagging
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI & Italian Senate meeting to decide on Confidence Vote timing (17:00BST)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets followed suit from the losses on Wall St with global risk sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and after the disruption in Hong Kong where there are growing fears of Chinese intervention. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was subdued but with losses stemmed by strength in tech and mining related sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) was among the underperformers as participants returned from the extended weekend and reacted to recent flows to the currency. Chinese markets also traded lower after Chinese Lending/Financing data disappointed and with heavy losses in Hong Kong after its airport was shut by a mass sit-in and although flights have since resumed, hundreds remained cancelled as they try to deal with the back log from the disruption. Furthermore, increased concerns China may intervene as the People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards the bordering city of Shenzhen, has added to the pressure for the Hang Seng (-2.1%) which declined to its weakest since early January, while losses in the Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were somewhat cushioned after the PBoC set a firmer than expected reference rate and continued its liquidity injections. Singapore’s STI (-0.9%) suffered from a double-whammy in which Q2 GDP missed estimates and the MAS dashed easing hopes by not considering an off-cycle policy meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher and the 30yr yield dropped to 0.2% for the first time in 3 years amid the risk averse tone and following the bull flattening in the US, although upside was capped amid lack of BoJ presence in the market and given that prices were already at record levels.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0326 vs. Exp. 7.0421 (Prev. 7.0221); weakest since March 2008.

Singapore GDP (Q2 F) Q/Q -3.3% vs. Exp. -2.9% (Prev. -3.4%). (Newswires) Singapore GDP (Q2 F) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%) Monetary Authority of Singapore said monetary policy is unchanged and it is not considering an off-cycle policy meeting.

South Korea plans to sharply increase budget spending next year for the parts and materials industries, in order to tide these industries over in wake of Japan’s export curds., according to Yonhap citing a top Presidential Official. (Newswires)

PBoC Offical says China are able to navigate all scenarios from US currency manipulation label, shocked that US Treasury Department labelled them as a currency manipulator; reiterated that the Yuan is at an appropriate level. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Hong Kong Airport has suspended all check-ins, according to local media. Follows on from Hong Kong’s Airport Authority noticing calls online for public assembly at the airport on Tuesday afternoon. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump has asked Japanese PM Abe to purchase a "huge amount" of US farm goods, according to Kyodo. (Kyodo)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson believes EU will cave in at the last minute to save Ireland from a no-deal Brexit, according to reports citing a Downing Street source. (The Sun)

The legal bid to stop UK PM Johnson from forcing a no-deal Brexit by suspending parliament will have a full hearing on 6 September, according to Politico's Casalicchio. (Twitter)

ComRes poll showed 54% support PM Johnson delivering the Brexit by any means including suspending Parliament. (Telegraph)

UK MPs are attempting to get the Court of Session in Edinburgh to rule that suspending parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit is “unlawful and unconstitutional”. The move is backed by over 70 MPs and peers including Lib Dem leader Swinson. (BBC)

UK Shadow Home Secretary Abbott has signalled that the Labour Party could be planning a vote of no confidence against PM Johnson once parliament returns in September. Abbott said Labour MPs are in talks with other parties on how best to proceed. (Guardian)

Italian Senate is to meet today at 1700BST to decide when to debate the League no-confidence motion in government, according to PD. (Newswires)

UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY Jun 3.7% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.4%, Rev. 3.5%)

- UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) Jun 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.6%)

- UK ILO Unemployment Rate Jun 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)

- UK Employment Change Jun 115k vs. Exp. 65k (Prev. 28k)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment Aug -44.1 vs. Exp. -28.5 (Prev. -24.5); Current Conditions Aug -13.5 vs. Exp. -7.0 (Prev. -1.1)

- ZEW sentiment point to a significant deterioration on the outlook for the German economy

- Most recent escalation in trade disputes, the risk of competitive devaluations and the increased likelihood of a no-deal Brexit place additional pressure on already weak economic growth

- This will most likely put a strain on developments of German exports and industrial production

EQUITIES

European stocks are lower across the board [Eurostoxx 50 -0.70%] following on from a downbeat Asia-Pac handover as global risk sentiment continues to be pressured by the US-China trade overhang and amid growing fears surrounding the violent Hong Kong protests and fears of intervention. Germany’s DAX (-0.9%) underperforms and hit levels last seen at the end of March after falling below a key tech level at 11600 (which was the reversal level during the May rout) with the aid of dismal German ZEW survey data and ahead of German GDP figures tomorrow. Sectors are mostly lower, with some resilience in defensive sectors as investors flock to “safe stocks”, whilst the energy sector outperforms amid the oil sector’s earlier gains, albeit this initial upside has since been retraced. In terms of individual movers, Henkel (-7.0%) rest at the foot of the Stoxx 600 amid a profit warning whilst it also noted that it does not envisage a H2 auto market recovery. Meanwhile, Rolls-Royce (-3.2%) shares continued to fall with today’s downside induced by a Moody’s downgrade to Baa1 from A3.

Exxon Mobil (XOM) is reportedly mulling the sale of some or all of its UK North Sea assets, valued up to USD 2bln, according to sources. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The Dollar remains divergent against G10 currency counterparts, but firm vs EMs as sentiment continues to favour safe-havens amidst ongoing unrest in Hong Kong and other parts of the globe, plus the US-China/EU etc trade conflicts. Hence, the DXY is still anchored around 97.500 and the index taking cues from moves in major basket constituents, like the Euro and Yen ahead of US CPI data.

EUR/GBP - The single currency and Sterling are both holding relatively steady vs the Greenback and thus each other, with Eur/Usd back above 1.1200 despite more dire Eurozone survey news in the shape of the latest ZEW findings for Germany and the bloc as a whole. The Euro is benefiting from its status as a refuge when risk aversion is high, if not rife, but 1.1220 Fib resistance may yet cap the upside having been respected on multiple tests recently. Conversely, the Pound has not really been able to sustain gains/momentum on the back of firmer than forecast UK pay metrics as Cable labours ahead of 1.2100 on persistent no deal Brexit jitters.

AUD/NZD/CAD - Some respite for the Aussie via an uptick in NAB business sentiment overnight and comments from RBA Assistant Governor Kent playing down the prospect of NIRP, as Aud/Usd pares losses from a test of key support towards 0.6770, but the Kiwi appears more vulnerable after relative outperformance or rather resilience yesterday with Nzd/Usd hovering around 0.6450 and Aud/Nzd just under 1.0500. In contrast, the Loonie is lagging either side of 1.3250 after last Friday’s disappointing Canadian jobs update and soft crude prices.

JPY/CHF - The Yen looks ripe for another attempt to breach 105.00 vs the Usd where more hefty option expiries reside and psychological bids/support are propping the headline pair in front of the 104.87 flash crash low, but the Franc has crossed 0.9700 against the Buck and approaching 1.0850 vs the Euro awaiting more Italian political developments alongside any response from the SNB to signs that the Chf is getting too strong.

EM - More broad losses across the region, and the Lira seemingly suffering from a lack of local participation as Turkey observe EID on top of increasingly bearish technical as Usd/Try has broken above the 200 DMA to expose the next significant upside chart level circa 5.6300.

RBA Assistant Governor Kent said lower rates are easing financial conditions in usual way and that recent broad-based easing will support demand, while he also noted the RBA is not targeting unemployment rate with policy and it is unlikely that negative rates are needed in Australia but added some unconventional policies are possible. (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Jul) 4 (Prev. 2). (Newswires) Australian NAB Business Conditions (Jul) 2 (Prev. 3)

Notable FX Expiries:

- USDJPY: 104.00 (746M), 105.00 (1.7B), 105.60 (785M)

FIXED INCOME

Some signs of decoupling or a deviation from inverse-correlations if not a more meaningful breakdown, but Bunds have not derived any additional impetus from a bleak ZEW survey that looks to have leant on the DAX more heavily. Perhaps the core Eurozone bond already priced in the risk of a bad miss vs consensus and was pre-emptive when posting a new 177.84 contract best pre-release, while Gilts are acknowledging the inflationary aspects of strong UK earnings and long end DMO issuance that took some digesting at such low yields. However, US Treasuries remain elevated and the curve compressed as the long end outperforms and 30 year cash teeters only a couple of bps from all time lows ahead of CPI.

COMMODITIES

Marginal losses in the oil complex with WTI and Brent futures choppy, with the former back below 55/bbl (after having visited the level earlier in the session) whilst the latter fell to around 58.50/bbl. News flow for the complex has again been light and the benchmarks seem to be moving off of sentiment/technical factors, with RBC yesterday highlighting that there is limited scope for short covering rallies due to positioning, i.e. speculators seem to have been unwinding long position rather than opening shorts. Nevertheless, participants will be on the lookout for geopolitical/trade developments, whilst Hong Kong also remains on the radar and whether China will intervene amid the rise in violent protests, which is likely to hit sentiment again, especially if US reacts with sanctions/tariffs. Looking at today’s docket, traders will await the weekly API crude data, expected to print a draw of 2.3mln barrels. ING notes that the narrowing of the WTI/Brent Arb (currently 3.6/bbl) could point to another weak of low exports as shown by the prior week’s EIA data. Elsewhere, gold remains on an upward trajectory amid safe-haven demand, with the yellow metal at a fresh 6yr high of 1526.7/oz. Meanwhile, copper is relatively flat on the day. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore traded in a tight range whilst steel futures rose as much as 3.0% as the pollution curb on steel mills dampens iron ore demand but also disrupts steel supply. GS sees a rebound in iron ore prices as “2019 is on track to post the seaborne market's first deficit in seven years”, and they see a deficit through 2020. Finally, Indonesia’s Minister noted that revisions to mineral ore export rules are currently being drafted. Indonesia initially planned to ban exporting nickel ore by 2022, in an attempt to build up its manufacturing base by using its raw resources but previously noted that bringing the deadline forward from 2022 will disrupt USD 4bln ore exports.

Goldman Sachs said iron ore market remains tight and sees iron ore prices to rebound to USD 115/ton in 3 months, while JPMorgan have a different view and see 2019 iron ore prices at USD 93/ton. (Newswires)

EUR/GBP - The single currency and Sterling are both holding relatively steady vs the Greenback and thus each other, with Eur/Usd back above 1.1200 despite more dire Eurozone survey news in the shape of the latest ZEW findings for Germany and the bloc as a whole. The Euro is benefiting from its status as a refuge when risk aversion is high, if not rife, but 1.1220 Fib resistance may yet cap the upside having been respected on multiple tests recently. Conversely, the Pound has not really been able to sustain gains/momentum on the back of firmer than forecast UK pay metrics as Cable labours ahead of 1.2100 on persistent no deal Brexit jitters.

AUD/NZD/CAD - Some respite for the Aussie via an uptick in NAB business sentiment overnight and comments from RBA Assistant Governor Kent playing down the prospect of NIRP, as Aud/Usd pares losses from a test of key support towards 0.6770, but the Kiwi appears more vulnerable after relative outperformance or rather resilience yesterday with Nzd/Usd hovering around 0.6450 and Aud/Nzd just under 1.0500. In contrast, the Loonie is lagging either side of 1.3250 after last Friday’s disappointing Canadian jobs update and soft crude prices.

JPY/CHF - The Yen looks ripe for another attempt to breach 105.00 vs the Usd where more hefty option expiries reside and psychological bids/support are propping the headline pair in front of the 104.87 flash crash low, but the Franc has crossed 0.9700 against the Buck and approaching 1.0850 vs the Euro awaiting more Italian political developments alongside any response from the SNB to signs that the Chf is getting too strong.

EM - More broad losses across the region, and the Lira seemingly suffering from a lack of local participation as Turkey observe EID on top of increasingly bearish technical as Usd/Try has broken above the 200 DMA to expose the next significant upside chart level circa 5.6300.

FIXED INCOME

Some signs of decoupling or a deviation from inverse-correlations if not a more meaningful breakdown, but Bunds have not derived any additional impetus from a bleak ZEW survey that looks to have leant on the DAX more heavily. Perhaps the core Eurozone bond already priced in the risk of a bad miss vs consensus and was pre-emptive when posting a new 177.84 contract best pre-release, while Gilts are acknowledging the inflationary aspects of strong UK earnings and long end DMO issuance that took some digesting at such low yields. However, US Treasuries remain elevated and the curve compressed as the long end outperforms and 30 year cash teeters only a couple of bps from all time lows ahead of CPI.

COMMODITIES

Marginal losses in the oil complex with WTI and Brent futures choppy, with the former back below 55/bbl (after having visited the level earlier in the session) whilst the latter hovers around 58.50/bbl. News flow for the complex has again been light and the benchmarks seem to be moving off of sentiment/technical factors, with RBC yesterday highlighting that there is limited scope for short covering rallies due to positioning, i.e. speculators seem to have been unwinding long position rather than opening shorts. Nevertheless, participants will be on the lookout for geopolitical/trade developments, whilst Hong Kong also remains on the radar and whether China will intervene amid the rise in violent protests, which is likely to hit sentiment again, especially if US reacts with sanctions/tariffs. Looking at today’s docket, traders will await the weekly API crude data, expected to print a draw of 2.3mln barrels. ING notes that the narrowing of the WTI/Brent Arb (currently 3.6/bbl) could point to another weak of low exports as shown by the prior week’s EIA data. Elsewhere, gold remains on an upward trajectory amid safe-haven demand, with the yellow metal at a fresh 6yr high of 1526.7/oz. Meanwhile, copper is relatively flat on the day. Elsewhere, Dalian iron ore traded in a tight range whilst steel futures rose as much as 3.0% as the pollution curb on steel mills dampens iron ore demand but also disrupts steel supply. GS sees a rebound in iron ore prices as “2019 is on track to post the seaborne market's first deficit in seven years”, and they see a deficit through 2020. Finally, Indonesia’s Minister noted that revisions to mineral ore export rules are currently being drafted. Indonesia initially planned to ban exporting nickel ore by 2022, in an attempt to build up its manufacturing base by using its raw resources but previously noted that bringing the deadline forward from 2022 will disrupt USD 4bln ore exports.

Nomura: Tense summer still has some room to run
content:
• Nomura think the rise in the VIX yesterday (Aug 12th) represents an aftershock to the first wave of higher volatility that has already arrived, as well as a foreshock to a second wave of volatility that Nomura think may arrive in late August or early September.
  • Ultra-short-term investors been unwinding long positions in US and European equities, and Nomura estimate that they are now tilting either market-neutral or slightly short.
  • See an ongoing risk that excessively large position adjustments by speculative players could drag longer-term investors into making panicky trades (selling stocks and buying bonds).
  • Global macro hedge funds are currently tentatively adding to their net long positions in both US stocks and US bonds. It seems that they are still generally of the view that the Fed will cut interest rates significantly and that US economic fundamentals will hold up fairly well.
  • For long/short funds there is a steady sector rotation involving the reduction of long positions in cyclicals and the build-up of long positions in defensives.
  • Trend-following CTAs have continued selling US equity futures. The S&P 500 could slip to 2,750-2,800 if CTAs were to back out of the entirety of their remaining net long position.
  • CTAs are accumulating USD/JPY shorts, and their net short position is back up to 74% of where it stood at its most recent peak, on 7 June. Nomura estimates, their aggregate net short position breaks even at 108.55.
  • CTAs are also rebuilding a net long position in USD/CNH, which is now about 60% of the size of their peak net long position on 29 May. Their outstanding longs break even at about 6.90 on average (by Nomura’s estimates), so it looks likely that CTAs will keep up their systematic buying.

content: Some faint consolidation after the initial salvo and further advance to 134.68 for the 10 year UK debt future, but only a relatively shallow pull-back to 134.53 vs yesterday’s 134.33 Liffe close before finding fresh underlying bids as the global bond bull run continues. Similarly, 3 month contracts are holding firm even though upcoming data is expected to show another acceleration in wages, while the curve retains a flatter bias overall as the search for yield forces investors to lengthen portfolio duration, with little sign of a meaningful consideration in cash yields or 2049 DMO supply at this stage.

subject: Bunds: on the brink of breaking fresh upside ground
content: In similar vein to Monday, the 10 year German benchmark has found a base and is regaining bullish momentum with the recovery from 177.50 opening Eurex lows pushing prices to within a few ticks of the 177.74 contract high, at 177.72. Buyers may now hold off until the EU cash bourse opens, but it seems almost inevitable that a fresh peak will be forthcoming and if not before then after the impending ZEW survey that is expected to show a further deterioration in sentiment and current conditions. Interestingly, a firm rebound in BTPs has not really sapped strength from Bunds as the date for an Italian confidence vote remains undecided and political parties are due to meet again later today.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets followed suit from the losses on Wall St with global risk sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and after the disruption in Hong Kong where there are growing fears of Chinese intervention. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was subdued but with losses stemmed by strength in tech and mining related sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) was among the underperformers as participants returned from the extended weekend and reacted to recent flows to the currency. Chinese markets also traded lower after Chinese Lending/Financing data disappointed and with heavy losses in Hong Kong after its airport was shut by a mass sit-in and although flights have since resumed, hundreds remained cancelled as they try to deal with the back log from the disruption. Furthermore, increased concerns China may intervene as the People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards the bordering city of Shenzhen, has added to the pressure for the Hang Seng (-1.5%) which declined to its weakest since early January, while losses in the Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were somewhat cushioned after the PBoC set a firmer than expected reference rate and continued its liquidity injections. Singapore’s STI (-0.9%) suffered from a double-whammy in which Q2 GDP missed estimates and the MAS dashed easing hopes by not considering an off-cycle policy meeting

FTSE 100

Flutter Entertainment (FLTR LN) – CEO Jackson has warned that barriers to the free movement of racehorses in Europe in the scenario of a no-deal Brexit would impact 1.5k UK races each year. These races result in around GBP 11.5bln of bets for British gambling firms. (FT)

National Grid (NG/ LN) – Co. had reportedly experienced three black-out “near misses” before Friday’s mass power outage. Industry sources claim the Co. has been aware of the growing potential for a wide-scale black-out for years. (Guardian)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equities followed suit from the losses on Wall St with sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and disruptions in HK
  • UK PM Johnson believes EU will cave in at the last minute to save Ireland from a no-deal Brexit, according to reports citing a Downing Street source
  • Italian Senate is to meet today at 1700BST to decide when to debate the League no-confidence motion in government
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI & ZEW, UK Employment, US CPI, UK 2049 Gilt Auction
  • Earnings: JD.com, Henkel, Swiss Life Holding

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets followed suit from the losses on Wall St with global risk sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and after the disruption in Hong Kong where there are growing fears of Chinese intervention. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was subdued but with losses stemmed by strength in tech and mining related sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) was among the underperformers as participants returned from the extended weekend and reacted to recent flows to the currency. Chinese markets also traded lower after Chinese Lending/Financing data disappointed and with heavy losses in Hong Kong after its airport was shut by a mass sit-in and although flights have since resumed, hundreds remained cancelled as they try to deal with the back log from the disruption. Furthermore, increased concerns China may intervene as the People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards the bordering city of Shenzhen, has added to the pressure for the Hang Seng (-1.5%) which declined to its weakest since early January, while losses in the Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were somewhat cushioned after the PBoC set a firmer than expected reference rate and continued its liquidity injections. Singapore’s STI (-0.9%) suffered from a double-whammy in which Q2 GDP missed estimates and the MAS dashed easing hopes by not considering an off-cycle policy meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher and the 30yr yield dropped to 0.2% for the first time in 3 years amid the risk averse tone and following the bull flattening in the US, although upside was capped amid lack of BoJ presence in the market and given that prices were already at record levels.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0326 vs. Exp. 7.0421 (Prev. 7.0221); weakest since March 2008.

US National Security Advisor Bolton said the US was expecting a Chinese delegation in September, but the Chinese have not said yes or no. (Newswires)

Hong Kong flight have resumed but with hundreds of flights said to remain cancelled, while the Hong Kong Airport Authority noticed calls online for public assembly at the airport on Tuesday afternoon. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q2 F) Q/Q -3.3% vs. Exp. -2.9% (Prev. -3.4%). (Newswires) Singapore GDP (Q2 F) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%) Monetary Authority of Singapore said monetary policy is unchanged and it is not considering an off-cycle policy meeting. 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson believes EU will cave in at the last minute to save Ireland from a no-deal Brexit, according to reports citing a Downing Street source. (The Sun)

ComRes poll showed 54% support PM Johnson delivering the Brexit by any means including suspending Parliament. (Telegraph)

UK MPs are attempting to get the Court of Session in Edinburgh to rule that suspending parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit is “unlawful and unconstitutional”. The move is backed by over 70 MPs and peers including Lib Dem leader Swinson. (BBC)

UK Shadow Home Secretary Abbott has signalled that the Labour Party could be planning a vote of no confidence against PM Johnson once parliament returns in September. Abbott said Labour MPs are in talks with other parties on how best to proceed. (Guardian)

US National Security Advisor Bolton said he conveyed the message to UK PM Johnson that President Trump is supportive of Britain's efforts to leave the EU and wants to have a comprehensive trade agreement as soon as possible, while he believes there will be overwhelming bipartisan support for a trade deal with the UK. (Newswires)

Italian Senate is to meet today at 1700BST to decide when to debate the League no-confidence motion in government, according to PD. In related news, Italian Deputy PM Salvini’s push for lower taxes and infrastructure spending could reportedly put the country at odds with the EU and rattle markets due to Salvini’s willingness to run a larger budget deficit. (Newswires/WSJ) 

FX

DXY was off the prior day’s lows but remained uneventful with price action stuck just below the 97.50 level following the recent decline in yields. The greenback’s major counterparts were mixed in which EUR/USD broke through 1.1200 to the downside, while GBP/USD was also subdued after a failed attempt to reclaim the 1.2100 handle and with UK PM Johnson looking to play chicken with Brussels as reports noted he believes the EU will cave in at the last minute to save Ireland from a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses recouped some of their recent losses but have far to go to fully recover from this month’s slip, while antipodeans marginally benefitted after a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate and slight improvement in Australian Business Confidence data, as well as comments from RBA Assistant Governor Kent who stated that it is unlikely negative rates will be needed in Australia although some unconventional policies are possible.

RBA Assistant Governor Kent said lower rates are easing financial conditions in usual way and that recent broad-based easing will support demand, while he also noted the RBA is not targeting unemployment rate with policy and it is unlikely that negative rates are needed in Australia but added some unconventional policies are possible. (Newswires)

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Jul) 4 (Prev. 2). (Newswires) Australian NAB Business Conditions (Jul) 2 (Prev. 3)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures traded sideways after having recently been tempered by resistance at USD 55.00/bbl and amid a lack of overnight drivers for the energy complex overnight, with participants now looking ahead to today’s API inventories for want of a better catalyst to spur prices. Elsewhere, gold saw mild gains amid the risk averse tone and as silver prices surged to test 2-year highs, while copper was lacklustre and reflected the broad risk averse sentiment across asset classes.

Goldman Sachs said iron ore market remains tight and sees iron ore prices to rebound to USD 115/ton in 3 months, while JPMorgan have a different view and see 2019 iron ore prices at USD 93/ton. (Newswires)

US

The T-plex continued its march higher to start the week, with ongoing Hong Kong tensions being the latest catalysts for bulls. The upward momentum in Treasuries and EGBs, specifically in the belly- to front-end, was spurred by the further weakening of the Chinese yuan in the earlier European session, and then was extended through till settlement as fears grew of further escalation in Hong Kong as Chinese military forces close in on the nation. By settlement the curve had considerably bull flattened, with the 10-year yield down by 9bps, and the 2-year yield down by about 4bps; the entire curve had flattened by 6bps whilst newswires highlighted that the 2s10s was at its narrowest since 2010. US T-note futures (U9) settled 22 ticks higher at 130-12.

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks conformed to global rout amid US-China trade overhang and Hong Kong protests concerns
content: Asia equity markets followed suit to the losses on Wall St with global risk sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and after the disruption in Hong Kong where there are growing fears of Chinese intervention. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was subdued but with losses stemmed by strength in tech and mining related sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) was among the underperformers as participants returned from the extended weekend and reacted to recent flows to the currency. Chinese markets also traded lower after Chinese Lending/Financing data disappointed and with heavy losses in Hong Kong after its airport was shut by a mass sit-in and although flights have since resumed, hundreds remained cancelled as they try to deal with the back log from the disruption. Furthermore, increased concerns China may intervene as the People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards the bordering city of Shenzhen, has added to the pressure for the Hang Seng (-1.5%) which declined to its weakest since early January, while losses in the Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) were somewhat cushioned after the PBoC set a firmer than expected reference rate and continued its liquidity injections. Singapore’s STI (-0.9%) suffered from a double-whammy in which Q2 GDP missed estimates and the MAS dashed easing hopes by not considering an off-cycle policy meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher and the 30yr yield dropped to 0.2% for the first time in 3 years amid the risk averse tone and following the bull flattening in the US, although upside was capped amid lack of BoJ presence in the market and given that prices were already at record levels.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks conform to global rout amid US-China trade overhang and Hong Kong protests concerns
content:
Asia equity markets follow suit to the losses seen on Wall St with global risk sentiment sapped by the continued overhang from the US-China trade war and following the disruption in Hong Kong where there are growing fears of an intervention by China. ASX 200 (-0.3%) is subdued but with losses stemmed by strength in tech and mining related sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) is among the underperformers as participants return from the extended weekend and react to recent flows to the currency. Chinese markets are also lower after Chinese Loans and Aggregate Financing data missed estimates with heavy losses in Hong Kong after its airport was shutdown by a mass sit-in and although flights have since resumed, hundreds remain cancelled as they try to deal with the back log from the disruption. Furthermore, increased concerns China may intervene after the People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards the bordering city of Shenzhen, has added to the pressure for the Hang Seng (-1.5%) which declined to its weakest since early January, while losses in the Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) have been stemmed after the PBoC set a firmer than expected reference rate and continued its liquidity injections. Singapore’s STI (-0.9%) was also weakened by a double-whammy after GDP data for Q2 missed estimates and the MAS dashed easing hopes in which it stated it is not considering an off-cycle policy meeting.

In FX markets, the DXY is off the prior day’s lows but remains uneventful with price action stuck just below the 97.50 level following the recent decline in yields. The greenback’s major counterparts are mixed with EUR/USD testing 1.1200 to the downside, while GBP/USD is subdued after a failed attempt to reclaim the 1.2100 handle and with UK PM Johnson looking to play chicken with Brussels as reports noted he believes the EU will cave in at the last minute to save Ireland from a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses have recouped some of their recent losses but have far to go to fully recover from this month’s slip, while antipodeans marginally benefit after a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate and slight improvement in Australian Business Confidence data, as well as comments from RBA Assistant Governor Kent that it is unlikely negative rates will be needed in Australia although some unconventional policies are possible.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher amid the risk averse tone and following the bull flattening in the US, although upside is capped amid a lack of BoJ presence in the market and given that prices are already at record levels.

content:
Air China (753 HK) - Co. cancelled 12 flights to and from Hong Kong today amid recent protests. (Newswires)

China Literature (772 HK) - Co. H1 adj. net CNY 390.0mln vs. Prev. CNY 483.5mln Y/Y, rev. CNY 2.97bln vs. Prev. CNY 2.28bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Protests

People's Armed Police were reportedly gathering and heading towards Shenzhen which borders Hong Kong, in advance of apparent large-scale exercises. This followed earlier news that Hong Kong Airport Authority activated an emergency center and were to cancel all flights not checked in by Monday afternoon amid serious disruptions in operations, while Hong Kong protestors later called for a retreat from the airport. (Global Times/SCMP) 

Trade

US National Security Advisor Bolton said the US was expecting a Chinese delegation in September, but the Chinese have not said yes or no. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin cited Chinese media which stated China can defeat any pressure of the US and noted that the US should not underestimate China. In other news, the Global Times Editor also tweeted that China Central government still exercises restraint and respects Hong Kong's high degree of autonomy under one country, two systems, although he has an intuition that riots will not be allowed to carry on like this. (Twitter/People’s Daily)

Other News

China is to issue the new market access negative list by the end of September in which it will reduce the number of items and further relax restrictions especially in the services sector, while the list will reportedly apply across the country and regions as well as departments will be forbidden from creating their own lists. (Newswires)

Data recap
